Name: Perfluorooctanoic acid
Description: Perfluorooctanoic acid is a fluoroalkanoic acid that is perfluorinated octanoic acid. It has a role as an environmental contaminant, a xenobiotic, a carcinogenic agent, a surfactant and an endocrine disruptor. It is functionally related to a perfluorooctane and an octanoic acid.

plant_concentrations.References: (1) Muller CE et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 8665-73 (2011)
plant_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctanoic acid concentration was reported in lichen, plants and mushrooms growing in the northern Yukon Territory and Northwest Territories of Canada; samples were collected June 24 to July 2, 2008 or Aug 2009(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Gebbink WA et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 7443-7449 (2009) (2) Braune BM, Letcher RJ; Environ Sci Technol 47: 616-24 (2013) (3) Kannan K et al; Chemosphere 49: 225-31 (2002) (4) Falandysz J et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 748-51 (2006) (5) Holmstrom KE, Berger U; Environ Sci Technol 42: 5879-84 (2008) (6) Holmstrom KE et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 80-84 (2005)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctanoic acid levels in herring gull eggs in 2007 from colonies spanning the Laurentian Great Lakes of North America were ranged from <0.10 to 2.6 ng/g wet weight(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.1 ng/g wet weight) in northern fulmar (Fulmarus glacialis) and thick-billed murre (Uria lomvia) eggs sampled 1971-2007 from Prince Leopold Island, Nunavut, Canada; in 2008, 2009 and 2011 perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in fulmar eggs at 0.17, 0.15 and 0.49 ng/g, respectively; in 2008, 2009, 2010 and 2011 it was detected in murre eggs at 0.23, 0.47, 0.05 and 0.05 ng/g, respectively; black guillemot (Cepphus grylle), black-legged kittiwake (Rissa tridactyla) and glaucous gull (Larus hyperboreus) eggs sampled in 2008 did not contain perfluorooctanoic acid(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in 2 of 81 bird livers collected from Japan (1997-1999) and Korea (1992-1994), the maximum concentration detected was 21 ng/g wet weight(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 60-100 pg/mL in blood samples from 16 eider duck (Somateria mollisima), collected from the Gulf of Gdansk in Feb 2003(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected (detection limit ng/g) in the muscle (0.60), kidney (1.2), adult liver (2.2), chick liver (0.76) or egg (0.99) of common guillemot (Uria aalge) samples from Stora Karlso Island in the Baltic Sea collected in 1989(5). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 3 ng/g) in guillemot eggs from Storla Karlso, Sweden, on the Baltic Sea, over the years 1968-2003(6).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Wang Y et al; Environ Sci Technol 42: 8146-51 (2008)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in eggs of little egret (Egretta garzetta), night heron (Nycticorax nycticorax) and great egret (Ardea alba) from Quanzhou (QH), Xiamen (XM), and Hong Kong (HK), South China; respective sampling dates were March-May 2004, March-May 2004 and March-May 2006(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-431 (2007) (2) Riebe RA et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol epub Dec 29 (2015). Available from, as of Apr 1, 2016: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=26714691 (3) Stahl T et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 62: 696-703 (2012) (4) Dai J et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 5647-5652 (2006) (5) Berger U et al; Organohalogen Compounds 66: 4046-52 (2004) (6) Riget F et al; Chemosphere 93: 1607-14 (2013) (7) Smithwick M et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 24: 981-986 (2005) (8) Ahrens L et al; Chemosphere 76: 151-158 (2009)
animal_concentrations.Value: Concentrations in various Japanese animal livers sampled in February 2005 were 0.64-7.3, 3.5-6.1, 1.1-3.0, and >0.07-0.60 ng/g wet weight for cormorant, racoon dog, eagle, and large-bill crow, respectively(1). Perfluorohexanoic acid was not detected in fox (Vulpes vulpes) livers and chamois (Rupicapra rupicapra) livers; fox were collected from Germany and chamois from Austria(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at <=45 and <= 7.4 ug/kg in 529 liver and 506 muscle tissue samples, respectively from wild boar (Sus scrofa) collected Hesse, Germany between 2007 and 2009(3). The compound was detected at concentration ranges of 0.33-8.20 ug/L and 0.32-1.56 ug/L in serum from captive red panda and giant panda, respectively, in China(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in all grey seal (concentration not reported), but none of the minke whale or pilot whale samples taken from Sweden, Denmark, Iceland and the Faeroe Islands(5). Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected in livers of 78 and 84% of ringed seals (Phoca hispipa) collected 1982 to 2010 in West and East Greenland, respectively, concentrations peaked in 2006 and 2008 at average concentrations of 1.0-2.2 and 1.2-2.4 ng/g wet weight, respectively(6). In polar bear livers (Ursus maritimus) from East Greenland, perfluorooctanoic acid had annual average concentrations of 4.8-14.0 ng/g wet weight with the lowest average in 2011 and highest in 2006(6). Perfluorooctanoic acid mean concentration in liver tissue from East Greenland polar bears (Ursus maritimus) was reported as 236 ng/g wet weight(7). Perfluorooctanoic acid levels in the liver of approximately 7 yr old harbor seals (Phoca vitulina) from the German Bight over the years 1999-2008 were reported as (year, ng/g wet wt): 1988, 1.0; 1999, 1.4; 2000, 2.4; 2001, 3.3; 2002, 0.6; 2003, 0.8; 2005, 0.9; 2006, 0.8; 2007, 1.0; 2008, 0.3(8).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Keller JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 39: 9101-8 (2005) (2) Keller JM et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 31: 1223-30 (2012)
animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in the blood of 73 loggerhead sea turtles (Caretta caretta) at 493-8140 pg/mL and at 2770-4250 pg/mL in six Kemp's ridley sea turtles (Lepidochelys kempii); samples were collected June-July 2003 along the coast of South Carolina, Georgia and Florida(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid concentrations were reported in the blood of five sea turtle species collected from Core Sound, NC; Kemp's ridley (Lepidochelys kempii), loggerhead (Caretta caretta), green (Chelonia mydas) and Juno Beach, FL; hawksbill (Eretmochelys imbreicata), leatherback (Dermochelys coriacea); samples were collected June-Oct 2006, June-Aug 2006 and April-May 2007(2).

animal_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctanoic acid was not detected (detection limit 0.007 ng/g wet weight) in grey seals (Halichoerus grypus) collected from the Baltic Sea from 1969-1976, 1980-1983 and 2004(1). Data for years that perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in seals are summarized below(1).

animal_concentrations.References: (1) Tomy GT et al; Environ Sci Technol 43: 4076-4081 (2009) (2) Tomy G et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 6475-6481 (2004)
animal_concentrations.Value: Relative percentages of perfluorooctanoic acid to total perfluorinated compounds in a western Canadian Arctic marine food web were reported as follows: arctic copepod (Calanus hyperboreus) 22; pelagic amphipod (Themisto libellula) 20; Artico cisco (Coregonus autumnalis) 10; Pacific herring (Clupea pallasi) 45; Arctic cod (Boreogadus saida) 60; ringed seal (Phoca hispipa) 10; beluga (Delphinapterus leucas) 5. Samples were collected from 2004-2005(1). Range concentrations of perfluorooctanoic acid in an eastern Arctic marine food web were reported as follows (ng/g wet weight): zooplankton 2.6; clams (Mya truncata; Serripes groenlandica) <0.2; shrimp (Pandalus borealis; Hymenodora glacialis) <0.2-0.5; Arctic cod (Boreogadus saida) <0.2-0.5; deepwater redfish (Sebastus mentella) <0.2-5.3; walrus (Odobenus rosmarus) <0.2-0.7; narwal (Monodon monoceros) 0.7-1.1; beluga (Delphinapterus leaucas) 1.0-2.8; black-legged kittiwake (Rissa tridactyla) <0.2; glaucous gulls (Larus hyperboreus) <0.2-0.3(2).

fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Concentrations of perfluorooctanoic acid (ng/g fresh weight) in edible fish, analyzed in 2001, from Lake Vattern and the Baltic Sea in Sweden were reported as follows(1):

fish_seafood_concentrations.References: (1) Awad E et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 8081-9 (2011) (2) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-431 (2007) (3) Yoo H et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 57: 552-60 (2009) (4) Holzer J et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 8046-52 (2011) (5) Berger U et al; Organohalogen Compounds 66: 4046-52 (2004) (6) Falandysz J et al; Environ Sci Technol 40: 748-51 (2006) (7) Olivero-Verbel J et al; Environ Pollut 142: 367-372 (2006)
fish_seafood_concentrations.Value: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in fish samples collected in 2003, 2006 and 2009 from Etobicoke Creek (Toronto, Canada) at 0.1-0.4, <0.1-0.2 and <0.1 ng/g wet weight, and in fish liver samples at <0.1-2.5, 0.5-1.0 and <0.1-1.3 ng/g wet weight, respectively(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid concentrations from Japanese fish sampled in February 2005 were reported as follows (ng/g wt weight): Scad 0.39; Sand fish <2.5; Jack Mackerel 10; Rainbow trout <2.5; Sardine <2.5(2). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at <0.3-2.2 and 0.3-2.7 ng/g wet weight in fish liver and blood, respectively of rockfish, shad and mullet collected in May 2006 from Lake Shihwa, Korea(3). Blue crab and oyster collected at the same time and location contained 0.3-0.8 and 0.3 ng/g wet weight, respectively(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 0.8-2.3 ng/g in 9 of 44 fish (15 perch (Perca fluviatilis), 6 pike (Esox lucius), 5 eel (Anguilla anguilla), 8 cisco (genus Coregonus), 10 roach (Rutilus rutilus)) collected from Lake Mohne, Germany(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in pike from Norway and eelpout from Denmark at unreported concentrations(5). Blood samples from 18 cod (Gadus morhua), collected from the Gulf of Gdansk in Feb 2003, contained perfluorooctanoic acid at <50-700 pg/mL(6). Perfluorooctanoic acid concentrations of <50-370 ng/mL were reported in mullet (Mugil incillis) from the north coast of Columbia (Cartagena Bay), sampled in December, 2003(7).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Awad E et al; Environ Sci Technol 45: 8081-9 (2011) (2) Bao J et al; Chemosphere 77: 652-657 (2009) (3) Bao J et al; Chemosphere 80: 123-30 (2010) (4) Pan Y et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 87: 152-7 (2011) (5) Li F et al; Li F et al; Chemosphere 84: 265-71 (2011) (6) Senthikumar K et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 79: 427-431 (2007)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SEDIMENT: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in sediment samples collected in 2003, 2006 and 2009 from Etobicoke Creek (Toronto, Canada) at <0.05-0.5, <0.05-0.2 and 0.1-0.2 ng/g wet weight, respectively(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid concentration in sediments collected in April 2008 from the Daliao River system of northeast China, a heavily populated and industrialized region, were <0.08-0.17 ng/g dry weight(2). Median concentrations in river sediments collected in March 2009 from 13 sites in the Zhujiang River, Guangzhou and 9 sites in the Hunagpu River, Shanghai (China) were 0.21 and 0.43 ng/g dry weight, respectively(3). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at less than detection limit to 0.90 ng/g dry weight in 23 sediment samples collected Dec 29-30, 2008 from the Haihe River, China(4). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at 0.9-3.7 ng/g in sediment samples collected from the Haihe River, China; samples were collected April to May 2010(5). Concentrations in Japanese river sediments from the Kyoto region sampled in February 2005 were reported as 1.6, 1.3, 3.9, 3.1, 2.3 and <0.1 ng/g dry weight at Kamo River, Uji River Station 1, Uji River Station 2, Tenjin River, Katsura River and Osaka River, respectively(6).

sediment_soil_concentrations.References: (1) Washington JW et al; Environ Sci Technol 44: 8390-6 (2010) (2) Pan Y et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 87: 152-7 (2011)
sediment_soil_concentrations.Value: SOIL: Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected in soil samples collected in Decatur, AL from fields where sludge had been applied; samples from 2007 contained 541-2531 ng/g dry weight (1.2 years after sludge application) and samples from 2009 contained 54-317 ng/g dry weight (2.7-4.7 years after sludge application)(1). Perfluorooctanoic acid was detected at <0.1-0.51, <0.1-0.50, <0.1-0.33 and <0.1-0.26 ng/g dry weight in 86 soil samples from suburban districts of Xiqing, Dongli, Jinnan and Beichen, Tianjin, China, respectively(2).
